    Pre-requisites

    There are two installs needed to complete the work in the exercise.

    Installing Pepper

    Install Pepper:

    We have a special fork of the Pepper analysis framework made for this exercise, which can be found at https://gitlab.cern.ch/cmsdas-cern-2024/long-ex-top-xsec

    1. checkout the exercise pepper repo (master branch!) and setup an basic environment (LCG 104) 
      git clone <repository url> pepper
cd pepper
source example/environment.sh
    2. make a python venv 
      python -m venv env_pepper
source env_pepper/bin/activate
export PYTHONPATH=$(pwd)/env_pepper/lib/python3.9/site-packages
    3. install pepper and required packages using pip 
      python -m ensurepip --upgrade
python -m pip install -r pip_requirements.txt
python -m pip install --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed --editable .

    (<repository url> can be ssh://git@gitlab.cern.ch:7999/cmsdas-cern-2024/long-ex-top-xsec.git or https://gitlab.cern.ch/cmsdas-cern-2024/long-ex-top-xsec.git )

    Note that the last command installs pepper as an editable module. This means that any changes you make to the pepper code will take effect the next time you call import pepper in a python script.

    To check that your installation of pepper is working, try running the following commands, which will run a quick test processor in debug mode.

    cd example
python3 -m pepper.runproc example_processor.py test_config.hjson -d

    Environment

    when logging into a new session, we want to setup the environment again as quickly as possible, and set some variables for access to grid resources. Copy the setup script to a personal file not tracked by git, e.g. cp example/environment.sh my_environment.sh. Open it and you will find some lines that will point to the python env you just made--add your pepper repo directory and uncomment them.

    Now, when you start a new session, you can go to your repo's base directory and run 

    source my_environment.sh
    to be fully set up to run pepper. This environment setup script will also need to be passed along to condor for batch submission.

    Note

    in this setup, we will give priority to packages installed in your python venv, while also continuing to include packages from your user installation and LCG locatable via your PYTHONPATH variable. This should allow you to mess around in PyROOT, or use other common packages, without needing to start a new session. But if you run into any environment troubles, ping a facilitator!

    Installing combine

    We don't really "use CMSSW" in this exercise, but we use the standard CMS statistical fitting tool combine, which is usually installed within a CMSSW environment. Follow the instructions below if you do not have an installed version from a previous exercise. This should be done in a fresh LXplus session.

    Combine v10 - brand new version! (for el9 machines)

    The installation method takes place inside CMSSW CMSSW_14_1_0_pre4 .

    source /cvmfs/cms.cern.ch/cmsset_default.sh
cmsrel CMSSW_14_1_0_pre4
cd CMSSW_14_1_0_pre4/src
cmsenv
git clone https://github.com/cms-analysis/HiggsAnalysis-CombinedLimit.git HiggsAnalysis/CombinedLimit
cd HiggsAnalysis/CombinedLimit
git fetch origin
git checkout v10.0.0
scramv1 b clean; scramv1 b -j 8

    Note

    You will want to use a separate terminal to run combine due to the many environment variables set by using CMSSW. When logging into a new session, go back to your CMSSW install directory and run: 

    cd src/
cmsenv
    and you can then run combine.

    CombineHarvester

    As of v10, the "CombineTool" scripts needed to make impact plots are included in the main combine installation, so a separate installation of CombineHarvester is not needed for this exercise. Currently, if you want to use CombineHarvester for its other features beyond those provided in the "combineTool" scripts, you will need to run it using a container (el7 or similar)
